winter-less-water.title: Winter watering
winter-less-water.message: In winter, reduce watering by half. Plants grow slower and need less water.

spring-fertilize.title: Time to fertilize
spring-fertilize.message: Spring is the best time to fertilize. Plants are waking up and need nutrients.

summer-early-water.title: Water early
summer-early-water.message: In summer, water early in the morning or at dusk to prevent evaporation.

fall-prepare.title: Prepare for winter
fall-prepare.message: Fall is a good time to prune and prepare your plants for the coming cold.

spring-repot.title: Spring repotting
spring-repot.message: If your plants have outgrown their pots, this is the best time to repot them.

summer-mulch.title: Protect the soil
summer-mulch.message: Add mulch or bark on top of the soil to retain moisture and protect roots from heat.

cloudy-less-evaporation.title: Cloudy day
cloudy-less-evaporation.message: Cloudy days have less evaporation. You can space out watering a bit more.

high-humidity-fungus.title: High humidity
high-humidity-fungus.message: With high humidity, watch out for fungus. Make sure there is good airflow between plants.

hot-day-shade.title: Very hot day
hot-day-shade.message: Above 30 degrees, consider moving sensitive plants to a spot with partial shade.

rain-coming.title: Rain tomorrow
rain-coming.message: Rain is expected tomorrow. You can skip watering outdoor plants.

windy-protect.title: Windy day
windy-protect.message: With strong wind, protect delicate plants and check that pots are stable.

cold-night.title: Cold night
cold-night.message: Low temperatures are expected tonight. Consider bringing cold-sensitive plants indoors.

yellow-leaves-overwater.title: Yellow leaves
yellow-leaves-overwater.message: If a plant has yellow leaves, it may be overwatered. Let the soil dry out between waterings.

brown-tips-humidity.title: Brown tips
brown-tips-humidity.message: Leaves with brown tips usually indicate low humidity. Try misting them with water.

droopy-leaves.title: Droopy leaves
droopy-leaves.message: If leaves are drooping but the soil is moist, it may be overwatering. Let it dry out.

pale-leaves-light.title: Pale leaves
pale-leaves-light.message: Pale or stretched-out leaves indicate a lack of light. Move the plant to a brighter spot.

check-drainage.title: Good drainage
check-drainage.message: Make sure all your pots have drainage holes. Roots should not sit in water.

rotate-pots.title: Rotate your pots
rotate-pots.message: Rotate your pots every 1-2 weeks so plants grow evenly and don't lean toward the light.

clean-leaves.title: Clean the leaves
clean-leaves.message: Wipe the leaves with a damp cloth every 2 weeks. This helps them breathe and absorb more light.

water-quality.title: Rested water
water-quality.message: Let tap water sit for 24 hours before watering. This allows the chlorine to evaporate.

morning-routine.title: Morning routine
morning-routine.message: Checking your plants every morning helps you spot problems early. A quick glance is enough.

group-humidity.title: Group your plants
group-humidity.message: Grouping plants creates a microclimate with more humidity. They help each other out.

quarantine-new.title: Quarantine
quarantine-new.message: New plants should be kept separate for 2 weeks before placing them with the rest. This prevents pests.

suculenta-propagation.title: Propagate your succulents
suculenta-propagation.message: You can propagate succulents with a healthy leaf: let it dry for 2-3 days and place it on moist substrate. Little roots will appear in a few weeks.

suculenta-substrate.title: Succulent substrate
suculenta-substrate.message: Use a mix of regular soil and perlite or coarse sand (50/50). Succulents need excellent drainage to avoid rotting.

suculenta-sunburn.title: Succulent sunburn
suculenta-sunburn.message: If your succulents have white or brown spots, it might be sunburn. Move them to partial shade and gradually acclimate them to direct sun.

suculenta-etiolation.title: Stretched-out succulents
suculenta-etiolation.message: If your succulent is stretching and the leaves are spreading apart, it needs more light. Move it closer to a window or give it a few hours of direct sun each day.

suculenta-watering-method.title: How to water succulents
suculenta-watering-method.message: Water succulents thoroughly and then let them dry out completely. The 'deep watering' method is better than giving them little sips frequently.

helecho-humidity.title: Humidity for ferns
helecho-humidity.message: Ferns love humidity. Mist the leaves 2-3 times a week or place a tray with pebbles and water underneath.

helecho-bathroom.title: Ferns in the bathroom
helecho-bathroom.message: The bathroom is an ideal spot for ferns: the shower steam gives them the humidity they need. Just make sure there's some natural light.

helecho-no-direct-sun.title: Ferns and direct sun
helecho-no-direct-sun.message: Never put a fern in direct sunlight -- the leaves will burn right away. Bright indirect light is the way to go.

helecho-brown-fronds.title: Dry fern fronds
helecho-brown-fronds.message: If you see brown or dried fronds, cut them off at the base. They won't come back and they drain energy from the plant.

cactus-dormancy.title: Winter cactus dormancy
cactus-dormancy.message: In winter, cacti go dormant. Water very little (once a month or less) and keep them in a cool spot. This helps them bloom better in spring.

cactus-overwatering.title: Soft cactus = overwatering
cactus-overwatering.message: If your cactus is soft or translucent, it's getting too much water. Take it out of the pot, let the roots dry, and repot it in dry substrate.

cactus-repotting.title: Repotting a cactus
cactus-repotting.message: To repot a cactus, wrap it in several layers of newspaper or use thick leather gloves. After repotting, wait 5-7 days before watering.

aromatica-harvest.title: Harvest herbs regularly
aromatica-harvest.message: Cutting herbs regularly makes them grow bushier. Never cut more than a third of the plant at once.

aromatica-pinch.title: Pinch off flower tips
aromatica-pinch.message: When basil or mint start flowering, cut off the flower tips. This way the plant focuses its energy on leaves instead of seeds.

aromatica-companion.title: Companion herbs
aromatica-companion.message: Basil near tomatoes repels aphids. Rosemary and lavender attract pollinators. Use herbs as companion plants in your garden.

aromatica-sun-needs.title: Sun for herbs
aromatica-sun-needs.message: Most herbs need at least 6 hours of direct sun. Without enough light, they lose flavor and aroma.

trepa-support.title: Support for climbers
trepa-support.message: Climbing plants need something to climb on: a moss pole, a trellis, or taut strings. Without support they grow sprawling and weaker.

trepa-aerial-roots.title: Aerial roots
trepa-aerial-roots.message: Aerial roots on climbers aren't a problem -- they're normal and help the plant climb. You can guide them toward the moss pole for a better grip.

trepa-propagation.title: Propagate climbers from cuttings
trepa-propagation.message: In spring you can take cuttings from your climbers. Cut below a node, remove the lower leaves, and place it in water until roots appear.

frutal-pollination.title: Fruit tree pollination
frutal-pollination.message: In spring, make sure your fruit trees get pollinators. You can help by gently brushing a soft paintbrush from flower to flower if you don't see any bees.

frutal-pruning-time.title: Winter pruning for fruit trees
frutal-pruning-time.message: Winter is the time to prune deciduous fruit trees. Remove dead branches, crossed limbs, and suckers so they produce better in spring.

frutal-fruit-set.title: Thinning fruit
frutal-fruit-set.message: If your fruit tree has lots of small fruits, remove some. It sounds crazy, but thinning lets the remaining ones grow bigger and sweeter.

floral-deadheading.title: Remove spent flowers
floral-deadheading.message: Cut off flowers as they fade. This way the plant doesn't waste energy making seeds and gives you more new blooms.

floral-bloom-cycle.title: Blooming cycle
floral-bloom-cycle.message: Flowering plants need more nutrients in spring. Add a fertilizer higher in phosphorus (the second NPK number) to boost blooming.

floral-light-hours.title: Light and blooming
floral-light-hours.message: Many flowers need a certain number of light hours to bloom. If your plant isn't flowering, check whether it's getting enough direct sun.

early-spring-pests.title: Spring pests
early-spring-pests.message: Warmer weather brings aphids and mealybugs. Check the undersides of leaves and new stems carefully. Early detection is key.

late-spring-growth.title: Explosive growth
late-spring-growth.message: At this point in spring, plants are growing like crazy. Make sure they have enough space, nutrients, and water to keep up the momentum.

summer-heatwave.title: Heatwave
summer-heatwave.message: Several days in a row above 35 degrees. Water more often, mist the leaves in the evening, and move pots to the shade if you can.

summer-vacation-prep.title: Going on vacation?
summer-vacation-prep.message: Before you leave: water thoroughly, group pots in partial shade, and set up inverted bottles for slow watering. Ask someone to check on them every 3-4 days.

fall-bring-indoors.title: Bring the sensitive ones in
fall-bring-indoors.message: Nights are starting to get chilly. Tropicals, succulents, and flowering plants that spent summer outdoors should come back inside now.

fall-reduce-fertilizer.title: Ease off the fertilizer
fall-reduce-fertilizer.message: In fall, cut back on fertilizing. Plants are starting to go dormant and don't need as many nutrients. Pushing them now weakens them.

winter-dormancy.title: Respect the rest period
winter-dormancy.message: In winter many plants stop growing. Don't worry if you're not seeing new leaves -- it's normal. Water sparingly and skip the fertilizer.

winter-indoor-humidity.title: Indoor humidity in winter
winter-indoor-humidity.message: Heating dries out the air. Mist your tropical plants, set up trays with water and pebbles, or group pots together to create humidity.

spring-check-roots.title: Check the roots
spring-check-roots.message: In early spring, check if roots are poking out of the drainage holes. That's a sign the plant needs a bigger pot.

fall-last-pruning.title: Last pruning of the year
fall-last-pruning.message: Before the cold sets in, clean up dead leaves and dried branches. Avoid heavy pruning now because new growth won't survive the winter.

winter-light-position.title: Make the most of the light
winter-light-position.message: Days are shorter in winter. Move plants close to bright windows. The winter sun is gentle and won't burn them.

summer-bottom-watering.title: Bottom watering
summer-bottom-watering.message: In summer, try watering from below: place the pot in a container of water for 15-20 minutes. The soil absorbs what it needs evenly.

spring-seed-starting.title: Seed-starting season
spring-seed-starting.message: September is ideal for starting basil, tomato, and parsley seeds. Use seed trays with moist substrate and keep them in good light.

fall-compost-leaves.title: Use those fallen leaves
fall-compost-leaves.message: Dry fall leaves are gold for composting. Pile them up, keep them moist, and in a few months you'll have top-notch homemade fertilizer.

uv-high-protect.title: Very high UV
uv-high-protect.message: The UV index is extremely high. Indoor plants near windows can get burned. Move the pots back a bit or use a light curtain.

dry-spell-alert.title: Dry spell ahead
dry-spell-alert.message: No rain is expected for the next 5 days. Outdoor plants will need extra manual watering. Pay special attention to the ones in full sun.

temp-swing-stress.title: Sharp temperature swing
temp-swing-stress.message: There's a big gap between the high and low today. That temperature stress can affect sensitive plants. Bring them indoors at night if you can.

consecutive-heat.title: Persistent heat
consecutive-heat.message: It's been hot for several days straight. Double your watering frequency and check that the soil isn't pulling away from the pot walls.

frost-risk.title: Frost risk
frost-risk.message: Cold plus high humidity means possible frost. Cover outdoor plants with frost cloth or bring pots inside tonight.

heavy-rain-drainage.title: Heavy rain
heavy-rain-drainage.message: Heavy rain is expected. Check that your outdoor pots aren't waterlogged. If they don't have good drainage, move them under cover.

low-wind-mist.title: Dry and still air
low-wind-mist.message: With little breeze and low humidity, plants transpire faster. A good time to mist the leaves and place a small dish of water nearby.

uv-moderate-outdoor-time.title: Moderate UV: ideal for acclimating
uv-moderate-outdoor-time.message: The UV is moderate -- perfect for giving indoor plants some outdoor sun time. Start with 1-2 hours in partial shade and gradually increase.

post-rain-check.title: After the rain
post-rain-check.message: After heavy rain, check your pots: empty saucers if they filled up and make sure mud isn't blocking the drainage holes.

extreme-wind.title: Very strong winds
extreme-wind.message: With winds over 50 km/h, bring lightweight pots inside and secure climbers to their supports. Weak branches can snap.

pest-spider-mites.title: Watch out for spider mites
pest-spider-mites.message: Hot, dry conditions are paradise for spider mites. Look for tiny dots on leaves or fine webs. Spray with soapy water or neem oil.

pest-mealybugs.title: Mealybugs
pest-mealybugs.message: If you see cottony white spots on stems or leaf axils, it's mealybugs. Remove them with a cotton swab dipped in rubbing alcohol or apply neem oil.

pest-aphids.title: Aphid alert
pest-aphids.message: Aphids show up in spring and summer on tender new growth. Try a strong spray of water, potassium soap, or introducing ladybugs to your garden.

pest-fungus-gnats.title: Fungus gnats
pest-fungus-gnats.message: Those tiny black flies come from moist soil. Let the top layer dry out between waterings and add a layer of coarse sand on top.

pest-white-mold.title: White mold on the soil
pest-white-mold.message: White mold on the substrate means too much moisture and poor airflow. Remove the moldy layer, let the soil dry out, and improve air circulation.

pest-scale-insects.title: Scale insects
pest-scale-insects.message: Brown bumps stuck to stems and leaf veins are scale insects. Scrape them off with a fingernail and apply neem oil as a preventive.

pest-leaf-spot.title: Leaf spots
pest-leaf-spot.message: Humidity plus heat is a breeding ground for fungus. If you see brown or black spots with a yellow halo, remove the leaf and improve ventilation.

pest-thrips.title: Thrips on your plants
pest-thrips.message: Thrips leave silvery marks on leaves. They're tiny and hard to see. Shake a leaf over white paper -- if you see little bugs moving around, treat with neem.

pest-root-rot.title: Root rot
pest-root-rot.message: Plants watered too frequently are prone to root rot. If the plant wilts even though the soil is moist, check the roots -- they should be white, not brown.

pest-neem-preventive.title: Preventive neem in spring
pest-neem-preventive.message: Applying neem oil every 2 weeks in spring prevents a ton of pests. Spray in the evening to avoid burning the leaves.

fertilizer-npk-basics.title: What is NPK?
fertilizer-npk-basics.message: Fertilizers list NPK: Nitrogen (leaves), Phosphorus (flowers and roots), Potassium (overall health). For green leaves use more N, for flowers use more P.

fertilizer-spring-schedule.title: Fertilize every 2 weeks
fertilizer-spring-schedule.message: In spring and summer, fertilize every 2 weeks at half the recommended dose. Little and often beats a lot all at once.

fertilizer-overfeeding-signs.title: Over-fertilizing signs
fertilizer-overfeeding-signs.message: White crust on the soil, burned leaf edges, or weak growth are signs of too much fertilizer. Water thoroughly to flush out built-up salts.

fertilizer-organic-options.title: Organic fertilizers
fertilizer-organic-options.message: Worm castings, compost tea, or banana peels are great organic options. They release nutrients slowly and improve soil structure.

fertilizer-winter-stop.title: Don't fertilize in winter
fertilizer-winter-stop.message: Dormant plants don't absorb nutrients. Fertilizing in winter saturates the substrate with salts and can burn the roots. Wait until spring.

fertilizer-succulents.title: Fertilizing succulents and cacti
fertilizer-succulents.message: Succulents and cacti need very little feeding. Use a specific fertilizer diluted to 25% of the recommended dose, only in spring-summer, once a month at most.

fertilizer-flowering.title: Fertilizer for blooming
fertilizer-flowering.message: Flowering plants need more phosphorus and potassium. Look for a fertilizer with a formula like 10-30-20 when blooming season starts.

fertilizer-banana-peel.title: Banana peel tea
fertilizer-banana-peel.message: Soak banana peels in water for 48 hours and use that water for watering. It's rich in potassium and flowering and fruit plants love it.

care-leggy-growth.title: Leggy growth
care-leggy-growth.message: If your plants are stretching with thin stems and spaced-out leaves, they need more light. It's common in winter. Move them to the brightest window.

care-repot-signs.title: Signs it's time to repot
care-repot-signs.message: Roots poking out the bottom, water draining straight through without wetting the soil, or stunted growth are signs it needs a bigger pot.

care-bottom-leaves-normal.title: Lower leaves drying out
care-bottom-leaves-normal.message: Older leaves at the bottom drying up is normal for most plants. The plant reabsorbs the nutrients. Only worry if many are dropping at once.

care-water-temperature.title: Water temperature
care-water-temperature.message: In winter, don't water with ice-cold tap water. Let the water reach room temperature before watering so you don't stress the roots.

care-soil-compaction.title: Compacted soil
care-soil-compaction.message: If water runs down the sides without soaking the soil, it's compacted. Gently poke it with a stick and loosen the top layer.

general-consistent-routine.title: Consistency is key
general-consistent-routine.message: Plants prefer a steady routine over erratic care. Better to water a little late than to skip and then flood them.

general-terracotta-vs-plastic.title: Terracotta vs. plastic pots
general-terracotta-vs-plastic.message: Terracotta pots breathe and dry out faster (better for succulents). Plastic pots retain moisture (better for ferns and tropicals).

general-finger-test.title: The finger test
general-finger-test.message: Stick your finger 2-3 cm into the soil. If it's dry, water. If it's moist, wait. It's the simplest and most effective way to know when to water.

general-patience.title: Be patient with new plants
general-patience.message: A new plant can take 2-4 weeks to acclimate. If it drops a few leaves at first, don't panic. Give it time and consistent care.

general-watch-pets.title: Plants and pets
general-watch-pets.message: Many common houseplants are toxic to dogs and cats. If you have pets, make sure plants are out of reach or choose pet-safe varieties.
